content.question: Assume good <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is produced in a competitive output market that is in long-run equilibrium. In the short run, the variable input is unskilled labor whose wage is determined in a competitive labor market. Suppose there is an increase in consumer demand for good <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Z</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following explains the resulting change in the labor market for unskilled workers in the short run?

choices.label: New firms will enter using more labor and more capital to produce good <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, lowering the price of good <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

With more output of good <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> produced, the supply of labor needed to produce good <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> increases, and the wage rate for unskilled workers will fall.

The price of good <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> increases and the labor demand curve shifts to the right along the existing labor supply curve, resulting in higher wages and employment of unskilled workers.
Since the market is in long-run equilibrium, economic profits are zero, and therefore the demand for labor remains unchanged.
The marginal factor cost of labor will decrease, leading to more unskilled workers being hired.

content.answer: The price of good <math alttext="Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Z</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> increases and the labor demand curve shifts to the right along the existing labor supply curve, resulting in higher wages and employment of unskilled workers.
